skill.name: spawn:terminal
skill.description: Spawn a new terminal window to run CLI commands (ffmpeg, curl, python, etc.). Use for non-AI command execution.
skill.summary: Spawn a new terminal window to run CLI commands (ffmpeg, curl, python, etc.). Use for non-AI command...
skill.author: Consiliency

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access operations exist within the skill directory. The skill provides instructions for AI agents on how to use the fork_terminal() function for CLI command execution.

content.user_title: Run CLI commands in a new terminal window
content.value_statement: AI assistants cannot directly execute CLI commands. This skill enables running terminal commands like ffmpeg, curl, and npm in a separate window for development and automation tasks.
actual_capabilities: Spawn a new terminal window for CLI command execution
Execute development commands like npm, python, and ffmpeg
Capture and return command output when requested
Write debug logs to file for troubleshooting
Verify command syntax using --help before execution
limitations: Cannot run AI agent spawning commands (use spawn:agent skill instead)
Requires the fork_terminal() function to be available in the environment
Output capture requires CAPTURE mode to be enabled
Limited to CLI commands, not interactive shell sessions

use_cases.title: Convert video formats
use_cases.description: Run ffmpeg commands to convert video files, create GIFs, or extract audio tracks.

use_cases.title: Run build commands
use_cases.description: Execute npm run build, webpack, or other build tools in a separate terminal window.

use_cases.title: Execute Python scripts
use_cases.description: Run Python scripts with proper environment setup for data processing and analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Simple ffmpeg
prompt_templates.prompt: Use spawn:terminal to run ffmpeg -i input.mp4 output.gif

prompt_templates.title: Build project
prompt_templates.prompt: Spawn a terminal and run npm run build for the current project

prompt_templates.title: Download file
prompt_templates.prompt: Use spawn:terminal to download the file using curl -O https://example.com/file.zip

prompt_templates.title: Python script
prompt_templates.prompt: Fork a terminal and run python data_analysis.py with capture enabled

output_examples.input: Run ffmpeg to convert my video.mp4 to a GIF
output: ‚úì Spawned new terminal with command: ffmpeg -i video.mp4 output.gif

best_practices: Always verify command syntax with --help before execution
Use CAPTURE mode when you need to process command output
Use LOG_TO_FILE for debugging when commands fail
Distinguish between CLI commands and AI agent requests
anti_patterns: Skipping the --help verification step for unfamiliar commands
Assuming you know the correct syntax without checking
Using this skill to spawn AI agents (use spawn:agent instead)
Running commands without understanding what they do

faq.question: What is spawn:terminal?
faq.answer: A skill that enables AI assistants to spawn terminal windows for executing CLI commands like ffmpeg, curl, npm, and python.

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Each tool must have the fork_terminal() function available.

faq.question: What commands can I run?
faq.answer: Any CLI command that runs in your terminal. Common examples include ffmpeg, curl, wget, npm, python, docker, and git commands.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides instructions to the AI. All command execution happens in your terminal. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why not use spawn:agent for commands?
faq.answer: spawn:agent is for spawning AI assistants. Use spawn:terminal for CLI commands like ffmpeg, curl, npm, and python scripts.

faq.question: How do I get command output?
faq.answer: Set CAPTURE=true to block and return output, or use LOG_TO_FILE=true to write output to a debug file for later review.
